notes: Fourth generation W177 (2018-present). Transverse FWD/AWD platform with MBUX infotainment. AMG A35 features 302 hp turbo with 4MATIC AWD. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz A-Class article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.0L I4 turbo (402 hp AMG) + mild hybrid
notes: Fifth generation W206 (2021-present). All engines feature 48V mild hybrid system with integrated starter-generator. AMG C43 produces 402 hp. Requires familiarity with 48V electrical architecture. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz C-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth generation W213 facelift (2020-present). All engines feature 48V mild hybrid system. I6 turbo uses EQ Boost technology. Coupe/convertible variants continue. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz E-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Seventh generation W223 (2020-present). All engines feature 48V mild hybrid EQ Boost. Advanced MBUX Hyperscreen available. Air suspension standard. Requires specialized diagnostic equipment for complex electronics. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz S-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation C118 (2019-present). Shares platform with A-Class. AMG CLA35 features 302 hp turbo with 4MATIC AWD. Coupe-styled sedan body. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz CLA-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation H247 (2020-present). Taller design than predecessor. AMG GLA35 produces 302 hp with 4MATIC. MBUX infotainment standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz GLA-Class article, January 2025 revision.

First generation X247 (2019-present). Boxy design with optional third-row seating. AMG GLB35 features 302 hp turbo. 4MATIC AWD standard on most models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz GLB-Class article, January 2025 revision.

First generation X253 facelift (2019-2023). Available in standard SUV and coupe body styles. AMG GLC43 features twin-turbo V6. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz GLC-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation X254 (2022-present). All engines feature 48V mild hybrid system. Based on W206 C-Class platform. Coupe variant discontinued. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz GLC-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation V167 (2019-present). Most engines feature 48V mild hybrid EQ Boost. AMG GLE63 S produces 603 hp. Available in standard and coupe body styles. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz GLE-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation X167 (2019-present). All engines feature 48V mild hybrid EQ Boost. AMG GLS63 produces 603 hp. Seven-passenger seating standard. Air suspension with E-ACTIVE BODY CONTROL available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz GLS-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation W463 (2018-present). Body-on-frame construction with three locking differentials. Independent front suspension. AMG G63 produces 577 hp. Requires familiarity with complex 4WD system. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz G-Class article, January 2025 revision.

First generation V297 (2021-present). All-electric flagship sedan with up to 107.8 kWh battery. 400V architecture. MBUX Hyperscreen available. Requires EV-certified technicians for high-voltage system. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz EQS article, January 2025 revision.

First generation V295 (2022-present). All-electric E-Class equivalent with up to 90.6 kWh battery. 400V architecture. AMG EQE produces up to 677 hp. Requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz EQE article, January 2025 revision.

First generation X243 (2021-present). All-electric GLB equivalent with 66.5 kWh battery. Optional third-row seating. 400V architecture. Requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz EQB article, January 2025 revision.

First generation (2014-present). Hand-built AMG V8 with dry sump lubrication. Available in multiple variants including GT S, GT C, GT R. Requires AMG-specific diagnostic tools. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-AMG GT article, January 2025 revision.
